The Binghamton City School District has been focusing on its efforts to safely reopen schools this fall. One of the district’s focus areas has been the sanitation and disinfection of its buildings.

As soon as the pandemic began, district administrators began exploring products that would sanitize classrooms, bathrooms, and other high traffic areas in an efficient manner. The BCSD has purchased 13 electrostatic sprayers that will be distributed throughout its buildings, as well as two larger backpack-electrostatic sprayers that can be used to disinfect larger areas, like cafeterias and gymnasiums, when necessary.

These electrostatic sprayers use positively charged ions that allow the disinfectant to adhere not only to the tops of hard surfaces like desks and counters, but also to the undersides of objects and on vertical surfaces. This allows for maximum exposure of the disinfectant. With these sprayers, an average classroom can be disinfected in under six minutes.

Congratulations to Binghamton High School for becoming the first high school in the Southern Tier region to earn a No Place for Hate designation!

To begin this process, a committee was formed, and met monthly to discuss topics and issues within the building and plan upcoming events. Throughout the 2019-2020 school year, BHS students and staff took part in a number of activities that focused on actively combating bias and bullying in order to stop the escalation of hate. One activity was the Chalk the Walk event, where students wrote positive and inclusive messages outside the high school. Students and staff also gathered together to learn about what it means to be a No Place for Hate school, and signed a Resolution of Respect.

We would like to recognize Principal Kevin Richman and former Assistant Principal Dario Vazquez (who is now building principal at Calvin Coolidge) for spearheading this important work. Well done, BHS! #BPatriotProud

Thank you Maureen for your many years of dedication and service to BCSD!

post_text: We’re bidding farewell to our Rotary exchange student, Jessica Chang, who returned home to Taiwan early due to the current health crisis. While we’re sad to see her time abroad cut short, we know home and family are the most important things during times like this. We are grateful for the time Jessica spent in Binghamton, attending BHS, playing basketball and experiencing American traditions. We wish her all the best!
shared_text:
Rotary Club of Binghamton
March 30 at 2:20 PM ·

Jessica made it home! 🇹🇼

Thank you to the Wright family and the Sellepack family for being so generous in hosting Jessica while she was here. Thank you to those who impacted her time spent in Binghamton.

We hope she enjoyed her stay, albeit cut short. With a very late night trip to the airport to send her home to her family, the Wright's enjoyed the last moments with her before the farewell. Making the most out of our last moments together.

We wish you the best! ❤️❤️
